content.raw:
When  compiling Gazebo  11 on  Windows with the latest CMake,  I experienced several CMake configuration warnings due to an unset new CMake policy on the automoc of  `.hh` files \([https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.17/policy/CMP0100.html](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.17/policy/CMP0100.html)\):

```restructuredtext
CMake Warning (dev) in gazebo/gui/CMakeLists.txt:
  Policy CMP0100 is not set: Let AUTOMOC and AUTOUIC process .hh files.  Run
  "cmake --help-policy CMP0100" for policy details.  Use the cmake_policy
  command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  For compatibility, CMake is excluding the header file(s):

    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/Actions.hh"
    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/ModelManipulator.hh"
    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/AlignWidget.hh"

    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/Editor.hh"

    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/EntityMaker.hh"
    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/GLWidget.hh"

  from processing by AUTOMOC.  If any of the files should be processed, set
  CMP0100 to NEW.  If any of the files should not be processed, explicitly
  exclude them by setting the source file property SKIP_AUTOMOC:

    set_property(SOURCE file.hh PROPERTY SKIP_AUTOMOC ON)

This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.
```

 and linking problem as apparently the automoc as not executed:

‌

```
  Automatic MOC for target gazebo_gui
     Creating library C:/idjl-ws/build/Gazebo/gazebo/gui/Release/gazebo_gui.lib and object C:/idjl-ws/build/Gazebo/gazebo/gui/Release/gazebo_gui.exp

ModelCreator.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
TimeWidget.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]

MainWindow.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
ModelRightMenu.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
RenderWidget.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
TimePanel.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
Actions.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
ApplyWrenchDialog.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
GLWidget.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
LogPlayWidget.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual struct QMetaObject const * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::metaObject(void)const " (?metaObject@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEBAPEBUQMetaObject@@XZ) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
ModelEditor.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual void * __cdecl gazebo::gui::DeleteAction::qt_metacast(char const *)" (?qt_metacast@DeleteAction@gui@gazebo@@UEAAPEAXPEBD@Z) [C:\idjl-ws\build\Gazebo\gazebo\gui\gazebo_gui.vcxproj]
```

‌

I just added the first instances of  the error to  avoid  making the issue unreadable. In theory the default OLD policy value  should provide backward compatibility, but instead in this case the `OLD`  setting of the policy is  not working, while  explicitly setting the `NEW` setting solves both problems. 

‌
content.html:
When compiling Gazebo 11 on Windows with the latest CMake, I experienced several CMake configuration warnings due to an unset new CMake policy on the automoc of .hh files (https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.17/policy/CMP0100.html):

CMake Warning (dev) in gazebo/gui/CMakeLists.txt:
  Policy CMP0100 is not set: Let AUTOMOC and AUTOUIC process .hh files.  Run
  "cmake --help-policy CMP0100" for policy details.  Use the cmake_policy
  command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  For compatibility, CMake is excluding the header file(s):

    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/Actions.hh"
    "C:/idjl-ws/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/ModelManipulator.hh"

I just added the first instances of the error to avoid making the issue unreadable. In theory the default OLD policy value should provide backward compatibility, but instead in this case the OLD setting of the policy is not working, while explicitly setting the NEW setting solves both problems.

‌

content.raw:
Hi,

we are working on pick and place project in ros melodic - using simulation on gazebo 9, and we encounter a problem with a slipping. Wideo of the behavior can be seen at this link: [youtube](https://youtu.be/FTD5REwIWUA)

the settings for our gripper and object are as follows:

gripper.gazebo.urdf:

```
    <!-- LinkRightFinger -->
    <gazebo reference="${robot_name}_rightfinger">
        <material>Gazebo/Grey</material>
        <kp>10000000.0</kp>
        <kd>1000.0</kd>
        <mu1>100.0</mu1>
        <mu2>100.0</mu2>
        <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
        <minDepth>0.003</minDepth>
    </gazebo>

    <!-- LinkLeftFinger -->
    <gazebo reference="${robot_name}_leftfinger">
        <material>Gazebo/Grey</material>
        <kp>10000000.0</kp>
        <kd>1000.0</kd>
        <mu1>100.0</mu1>
        <mu2>100.0</mu2>
        <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
        <minDepth>0.003</minDepth>
    </gazebo>
```

model.sdf:

```
    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version='1.6'>
      <model name="cuboid">
        <static>0</static>
        <link name='link'>
          <inertial>
            <mass>0.10</mass>
            <inertia>
              <ixx>0.0002988</ixx>
              <ixy>0.000000</ixy>
              <ixz>0.000000</ixz>
              <iyy>0.0002988</iyy>
              <iyz>0.000000</iyz>
              <izz>0.00005976</izz>
            </inertia>
          </inertial>
          <collision name='collision'>
            <geometry>
              <box>
                <size>0.060 0.060 0.180</size>
              </box>
            </geometry>
            <surface>
              <friction>
                <ode>
                  <mu>100</mu>
                  <mu2>100</mu2>
                </ode>
              </friction>
              <contact>
                <ode>
                  <kp>1000000.0</kp>
                  <kd>100.0</kd>
                  <max_vel>1.0</max_vel>
                  <min_depth>0.002</min_depth>
                </ode>
              </contact>
            </surface>
          </collision>
          <visual name='visual'>
            <geometry>
              <box>
                <size>0.060 0.060 0.180</size>
              </box>
            </geometry>
            <material>
              <script>
                <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
                <name>Gazebo/Red</name>
              </script>
            </material>
          </visual>
          <velocity_decay>
            <linear>0.000000</linear>
            <angular>0.000000</angular>
          </velocity_decay>
          <self_collide>0</self_collide>
          <kinematic>0</kinematic>
          <gravity>1</gravity>
        </link>
      </model>
    </sdf>
```

and controller settings - control.yaml:

```
    panda_hand_controller:
        type: position_controllers/JointTrajectoryController
        joints:
            - panda_finger_joint1
            - panda_finger_joint2
        constraints:
            goal_time: 0.6
            stopped_velocity_tolerance: 0
            panda_finger_joint1: {trajectory: 0.1, goal: 0.1}
            panda_finger_joint2: {trajectory: 0.1, goal: 0.1}


        stop_trajectory_duration: 1.0

        state_publish_rate: 100
    joint_position_controller:
        type: panda_simulation/JointPositionController
        arm_id: panda
        joint_names:
            - panda_joint1
            - panda_joint2
            - panda_joint3
            - panda_joint4
            - panda_joint5
            - panda_joint6
            - panda_joint7
        gains: [1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1]
```

i know of a JenniferBuehler/gazebo-pkgs grasping pluggin witch i implemented solving this issiue - but i dont like this approach and i want to do it in less cheaty way.

The physics engine we are using is ODE, and i didnt try to change it yet. Can it be a source of our problem?

and controller settings - control.yaml:

    panda_hand_controller:
        type: position_controllers/JointTrajectoryController

            - panda_finger_joint1
            - panda_finger_joint2

            panda_finger_joint2: {trajectory: 0.1, goal: 0.1}


        stop_trajectory_duration: 1.0

        state_publish_rate: 100
    joint_position_controller:
        type: panda_simulation/JointPositionController
        arm_id: panda
        joint_names:
            - panda_joint1
            - panda_joint2
            - panda_joint3
            - panda_joint4
            - panda_joint5
            - panda_joint6
            - panda_joint7
        gains: [1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1]

i know of a JenniferBuehler/gazebo-pkgs grasping pluggin witch i implemented solving this issiue - but i dont like this approach and i want to do it in less cheaty way.

The physics engine we are using is ODE, and i didnt try to change it yet. Can it be a source of our problem?

values.title: Gazebo fails to launch under Wayland

content.raw:
Fedora 31's Qt uses the `qwayland` Qt Platform Abstraction \(QPA\) by default when running in a GNOME wayland session.  When the `qwayland` platform is specified, Gazebo fails to launch, as OGRE is incompatible with wayland.  See [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show\_bug.cgi?id=1815270](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1815270) for more details.

When the QPA is overridden to use the X11 `xcb` QPA, gazebo will run without issue.
content.html:
Fedora 31's Qt uses the qwayland Qt Platform Abstraction (QPA) by default when running in a GNOME wayland session. When the qwayland platform is specified, Gazebo fails to launch, as OGRE is incompatible with wayland. See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1815270 for more details.

When the QPA is overridden to use the X11 xcb QPA, gazebo will run without issue.

values.title: Unable to install Gazebo 11 in Ubuntu 20.04 because of missing dependency in 'libboost-regex1.71.0-icu65'

content.raw:
Even though there is no official release of both, it might be worthy to take into consideration that there a dependencies missing. Trying to install Gazebo 11 \(`gazebo11` and `libgazebo11-dev`\) in Ubuntu 20.04 in a Docker container with base in `ubuntu:20.04` results in the following error:

```shell
The following packages have unmet dependencies:
 gazebo11 : Depends: libboost-regex1.71.0-icu65 but it is not installable
            Depends: libgazebo11 (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed
 libgazebo11-dev : Depends: libgazebo11 (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed
                   Depends: gazebo11-plugin-base (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed
```

`libboost-regex1.71.0-icu66` is already available in Focal. Now I am not sure if this is a problem of the base container not being updated, or if this is a real dependency issue \(I don’t have 20.04 natively installed or in a VM to try it\).

Any pointers? Thank you
content.html:
Even though there is no official release of both, it might be worthy to take into consideration that there a dependencies missing. Trying to install Gazebo 11 (gazebo11 and libgazebo11-dev) in Ubuntu 20.04 in a Docker container with base in ubuntu:20.04 results in the following error:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
 gazebo11 : Depends: libboost-regex1.71.0-icu65 but it is not installable
            Depends: libgazebo11 (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed
 libgazebo11-dev : Depends: libgazebo11 (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed
                   Depends: gazebo11-plugin-base (= 11.0.0-1~focal) but it is not going to be installed

libboost-regex1.71.0-icu66 is already available in Focal. Now I am not sure if this is a problem of the base container not being updated, or if this is a real dependency issue (I don’t have 20.04 natively installed or in a VM to try it).

Any pointers? Thank you

content.raw:
When I first got the ‘namespace not found error’, I didn’t know what to do. I had just tried to launch gazebo straight from the terminal. Assuming it was a problem with Kubuntu, which had shown other issues, I installed Ubuntu 16.04 over it. But I saw the same error again. After hours of searching online, I found that the issue was that the required models weren’t being downloaded. I fixed my problem by manually downloading the models and placing them in '/usr/share/gazebo-7/models'. 

The issue was that the url from which Gazebo was trying to download the models, ‘[http://gazebosim.org/models’](http://gazebosim.org/models’), is invalid. So, either the webpage has to be fixed, or the links in the ‘setup.bash’ files must be changed.
content.html:
When I first got the ‘namespace not found error’, I didn’t know what to do. I had just tried to launch gazebo straight from the terminal. Assuming it was a problem with Kubuntu, which had shown other issues, I installed Ubuntu 16.04 over it. But I saw the same error again. After hours of searching online, I found that the issue was that the required models weren’t being downloaded. I fixed my problem by manually downloading the models and placing them in '/usr/share/gazebo-7/models'.

The issue was that the url from which Gazebo was trying to download the models, ‘http://gazebosim.org/models’, is invalid. So, either the webpage has to be fixed, or the links in the ‘setup.bash’ files must be changed.

values.title: Re-submit pull request #2768 on github "Moving the center of gravity of a link with joints in ODE"

content.raw: PR #2768 was submitted on bitbucket to fix #1981, but it was not reviewed before the GitHub migration. After the migration, this pull request should be re-opened and reviewed.
content.html: PR #2768 was submitted on bitbucket to fix #1981, but it was not reviewed before the GitHub migration. After the migration, this pull request should be re-opened and reviewed.
